awd_titl_txt: Nonlocal PDE Models in Biology and Fluids
awd_abstract_narration:
Many phenomena in physics and biology involve nonlocal effects, where distant parts are allowed to influence each other. These phenomena are usually modeled by partial differential equations (PDE) that incorporate nonlocal and nonlinear terms. The purpose of this project is to study qualitative properties of solutions to a variety of nonlocal equations, such as the Keller-Segel equation that models the collective motion of cells which are attracted by a self-emitted chemical substance; the surface quasi-geostrophic equation arising in the study of atmospheric turbulence and oceanic flows; and the aggregation equation, which describes the movement of large swarms of insects. The goal is to develop new mathematical tools to analyze basic properties of solutions in order to gain a better understanding of the physical and biological models.

Mathematically, the following questions will be investigated in this project: For fluid models such as a 1D analog of Boussinesq equation, does the solutions to the PDE have global well-posedness, or can the solution form a singularity in finite time? For the aggregation equation with attractive kernels, where formation of singularities always happens in finite time, the goal is to find some notion of solutions that can be extended past the blow-up time. We will also study a nonlocal system motivated by coral broadcast spawning, where two densities evolve under diffusion, reaction and chemotaxis, and rigorously analyze the effect of chemotaxis on the reaction rate. The nonlocal and nonlinear nature of these equations poses many challenges in the analysis. To overcome these difficulties, we will apply and develop a variety of analysis tools including energy methods, comparison principle, optimal transport theory and probabilistic methods.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Long range interactions can be observed in a broad class of natural phenomena, ranging from fluid dynamics to animal swarms. Mathematically, these phenomena can be modeled by partial differential equations (PDE) with both nonlocal and nonlinear terms.  For these equations, although the short-time existence result of solutions have been well established, many questions regarding their long time behavior remain open. The aim of this project is to rigorously study whether solutions to nonlocal equations can form a singularity in finite time, and what is the long time dynamics if solutions exist globally in time. 

The first main direction is the formation of finite time singularity in fluid equations. The question of global regularity v.s. finite time blow-up remains open for many fundamental fluid equations, such as the 3D Navier-Stokes and Euler equation. In 2D more is known, although the picture is far from complete. For the 2D Euler equation, global regularity has long been established for both smooth initial data and patch-like initial data. However, this question has not been resolved for the surface quasi- geostrophic (SQG) equation, which is a 2D equation that shares many features of the 3D Euler equation. Together collaborators, we study a natural family of equations that interpolates between 2D Euler and SQG. When the equation is set up in the half plane, we prove both local regularity and finite time singularity formation for the patch solution. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first proof of singularity formation in an incompressible fluid equation of this type. In order to bridge the gap between 2D and 3D equations, we also study some 1D models of the 3D axisymmetric Euler equation, and show that these equation can have a finite-time blow-up.

The second main direction is the Keller-Segel equation. It is a nonlocal PDE modeling chemotaxis, where cells are attracted by a self-emitted chemical substance. When the equation is set up in 2D with a degenerate diffusion term, even the existence and uniqueness of the global minimizer of this functional is known, it was unknown whether solutions converge to the global minimizer, due to the non-convexity of the functional. In a recent joint work with collaborators, we use Steiner symmetrization techniques to prove radial symmetry of stationary solutions up to a translation. As a consequence, we show that every solution must converge to a translation of the global minimizer as the time goes to infinity. In another work, we show that as the power of the degenerate diffusion goes to infinity, the solution solves a free boundary problem similar to the Hele-Shaw equation, and we can obtain some convergence rate towards the global minimizer in this case.  

The PI presented her results in seminar, workshop and conferences (around 10-12 talks per year). She also actively interacted with undergraduate and graduate students at both UW-Madison and Georgia Tech. 


Last Modified: 08/06/2017
Modified by: Yao Yao
